awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Reactive Evolution of Ion-Battery Interfaces through a Versatile Single-Site Ionic Interrogation and Imaging Toolset
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division. Professor Joaquin Rodriguez Lopez of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is developing new tools and techniques for imaging chemical reactions occurring on energy-dense battery electrodes with the intention of improving their performance and safety. To meet the challenge of exploring complex reactions on battery interfaces, the project utilizes a powerful approach to independently address redox and ionic reactivity. Advanced concepts on battery materials are fully integrated into an educational and outreach plan that introduces the local undergraduate and K-12 Hispanic population to learning opportunities in energy science. The results of this project inform guidelines for designing better batteries and respond to the NSF?s mission of serving the national interest by advancing the progress of energy sciences and by allowing the USA to remain at the forefront of battery technologies.  

This project focuses on elucidating the early signs, evolution, and consequences of uneven chemical reactivity on carbon and silicon battery interfaces as these strongly impact cycling performance, materials utilization, and risk of catastrophic failure. In situ methods for the localized measurement of ion insertion reactions and of interfacial redox reactivity are being developed. Correlating these two aspects helps to identify and address the factors that lead to battery underperformance at the level of single sites and nanostructures. An educational and outreach plan developed by Prof. Rodriguez Lopez takes each contribution towards the research goals as a teaching and learning opportunity. Undergraduate students participate in the development of demonstration kits and computational tools related to electrochemical energy that are delivered to local high school and to K-12 Hispanic students through collaborations with teacher and student organizations. This project has a broad societal impact as it addresses the discovery of phenomena that lead to real-world performance concerns on everyday energy technologies and involves the future workforce in the solution of these energy-related challenges.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This NSF funded research allowed the introduction of new electrochemical imaging and localized measurement techniques to probe interphase formation and ion intercalation on electrode interfaces relevant to battery technologies. The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is a multi-component and dynamic barrier that forms at the surfaces of anodes within Li+ batteries as they are polarized negatively, incorporating ions and products of electrolyte breakdown, and enabling the long-term operation of the anode.  The electronically insulating but ionically conductive nature  of the SEI enables ions to reversibly insert into the host electrode. Upcoming technologies, such as Na+ and K+ batteries, also present SEI structures, though their properties and stability require improvements to perform as well as their Li+ counterparts. Other types of batteries may present interphases of their own, and developing strategies to keep track of the redox and ionic reactivity displayed by these interphases as they form is crucial to ensuring that the resulting structures work optimally. Thus, this project set to create tools for interrogating and exploring the local interfacial chemical reactivity of model battery electrodes as a function of structure and chemical perturbations with the intention of better understanding the SEI and its impact on battery performance. 

Our core strategy was the development of a versatile micro- and nano-resolved in situ platform based on scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) in dry box conditions (air and moisture free) using mercury amalgam and conductive polymer probes for detection of ion fluxes at operating electrodes. We also improved the resolution of SECM redox-recycling strategies to probe the electronic passivation accompanying SEI formation in tandem with other spectroscopic and X-ray based characterization techniques. The innovative toolset enabled by this project allowed us to explore the evolution of interfacial reactivity, particularly at the onset of SEI formation. Redox probes allowed us to track the passivation of graphitic electrodes in real time, while ion-sensitive SECM allowed us to detect the incorporation of ions onto the SEI as it formed. Notably, these techniques allowed us to observe reversible ion exchange processes on the SEI formed at the edge plane of graphitic carbon (a model electrode for carbon-based anodes), to estimate the rate of Li+ intercalation, to image SEIs formed on graphene flakes, and to correlate redox and ionic measurements to evaluate the impact of different electrolytes on the SEI formation process. While the project was strongly focused on the detection of alkali ions, it also allowed us to seed methods in the detection of anions used in battery electrolytes and in the observation of passivation processes when redox-active molecules decompose on carbon surfaces. Altogether, this NSF project enabled new measurement capabilities that help understand and improve interfacial battery chemistries and create application prospects for many other electrodes used in energy storage, energy conversion, and sensing.

This project provided learning and participation opportunities to students at all levels of university instruction, and reached students from elementary to high-school. The PI involved a diverse group of undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate students (including Hispanic, female, and first-generation participants) in activities directly related to research on new measurement methodologies using scanning probe microscopy, on the learning of techniques used to characterize materials, and on the use of computational methods to quantitatively understand measurements. These activities support workforce development in key aspects of energy technologies. The results of the research were disseminated in referred journals in the discipline of analytical chemistry as well as in journals dedicated to broader aspects of chemistry, thus reaching broad audiences. The participants engaged in seminars, workshops, and conferences to share the knowledge generated and details about the measurement techniques developed. Project-specific educational experiences were created through the "Electrochemical Bootcamp" program, which instructed beginner, intermediate, and advanced students from universities in Illinois and elsewhere in electrochemical concepts, from setting up basic electrochemical experiments, to cutting edge techniques in electrochemical imaging using SECM, thus creating synergy with the techniques developed. Specifically for this project, we developed an activity for the reactive imaging of a graphene electrode using feedback SECM, and reviewed various concepts related to surface electrochemistry. Public lectures and outreach through the "Cena y Ciencias" program allowed the PI to reach underrepresented minority students of various ages to improve their scientific thinking and literacy, as well as to make them aware of the scientific outcomes and opportunities generated by this project. Specifically, the PI developed and presented two activities related to analytical measurement and spectroscopy introducing the concept of using probes and instruments to measure invisible substances and processes.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Joaquin Rodriguez Lopez
